review.title: Multi-Objective AI Planning: Comparing Aggregation and Pareto Approaches
review.abstract: Most real-world Planning problems are multi-objective, trying to minimize both the makespan of the solution plan, and some cost of the actions involved in the plan. But most, if not all existing approaches are based on single-objective planners, and use an aggregation of the objectives to remain in the single-objective context. Divide and Evolve (DaE) is an evolutionary planner that won the temporal deterministic satisficing track at the last International Planning Competitions (IPC). Like all Evolutionary Algorithms (EA), it can easily be turned into a Pareto-based Multi-Objective EA. It is however important to validate the resulting algorithm by comparing it with the aggregation approach: this is the goal of this paper. The comparative experiments on a recently proposed benchmark set that are reported here demonstrate the usefulness of going Pareto-based in AI Planning.

metadata.title: Multi-Objective AI Planning: Comparing Aggregation and Pareto Approaches

sections.heading: 3 Multi-Objective Background
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Pareto-based Multi-Objective Divide-and-Evolve
sections.text: Two modifications of the DaEYAHSP are required to turn it into an EMOA: instead of the single target selection used in the single target context, a multi-objective selection engine is used and the value of both targets (Makespan and Costs) is calculated for both individuals. The first modification is simple and several alternatives have been tested within [16]. The conclusion is that the indicator-based selection works best using the Hypervolume Difference Indicator [19] - and only this one is used below, here referred to as MO-DaEYAHSP. As explained above, suitability is calculated by YAHSP and YAHSP, as all known planners to date, as a one-objective planner. Nevertheless, since PDDL 3.0 [6], it is possible to specify the other quantities of interest to be calculated during the execution of the final plan without prejudice to the search.

sections.heading: 3.2 Aggregation-based Multi-Objective Divide-and-Evolve
sections.text: Aggregation is certainly the simplest and most common way to handle multi-objective problems with a single optimization algorithm: A number of single-objective optimization problems are addressed alternately, and the suitability of each of these problems is defined by a linear combination of objectives. In the case of macespan and costs, both of which are to be minimized, each linear combination can be defined by a single parameter α in [0, 1]. In the following, Fα will denote the number of non-dominated individuals within the unification of all end populations7. Note that different alpha runs may have different optimal values for their parameters: a "run" of the aggregation method thus boils down to multiple alpha runs and returns the number of non-dominated individuals within the unification of all end populations7. Note that different alpha runs may have different optimal values for their parameters: a complete parameter-tuning run of parameters must be performed for each alpha run to ensure a fair comparison with other run.

sections.heading: 3.3 Multi-Objective Benchmarks:
sections.text: In order to turn this problem into a multi-objective one, costs (or risks) are added to the flight actions that land in one of the central cities, leading to two types of problems: InMultiZenoCost, the second goal being the total costs incurred for each landing of an aircraft in a central city; in MultiZenoRisk, the second goal is the maximum risk that occurs in the complete execution of a plan; both must be minimized; the complexity of the cases can be increased by adding more passengers: instances of 3, 6 and 9 passengers are used here; and finally, by matching the values of flight duration and cost / risk, different forms of the Pareto front can be achieved: Figure 1 summarizes three possible instances for the MultiZeno domain, and the corresponding fronts for the passengers are presented in Figure 2.

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Settings
sections.text: It is widely accepted that the large number of parameters of most EAs, even if it is not a source of flexibility, is also a weakness, since a poor parameter setting can ruin the performance of the most promising algorithm. In this work, unless stated otherwise, there are many methods available today for offline parameters that should be used within an evolutionary experiment, despite their enormous computing costs. In this work, unless stated otherwise, the user-defined parameters of both MO-DaEYAHSP and DaEYAHSP shown in Table 1 are anew for each instance, using the ParamILS framework. ParamILS performs an iteratedLocal search within the space of possible parameter configurations, evaluating each configuration by optimizing the algorithm with this configuration.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion and Conclusion
sections.text: The experiments presented in this paper have somehow demonstrated the greater efficiency of the Pareto-based approach to multi-objective AI planning MODaEYAHSP compared to the more traditional approach by aggregating the objectives of Agg-DaEYAHSP. The case is clear on MultiZeno6, and on the various instances experimented with, where MO-DaEYAHSP finds the entire Pareto front robust (with the exception of the convex instance), whereas Agg-DaEYAHSP performs much worse in all aspects, including the MultiZeno9 instance, despite the better hypervolume indicator: in fact, a few more points are found on the Pareto front, but the global picture remains a poor approximation of the Pareto front. Other experiments on more instances are necessary to confirm these initial results, and the ongoing work concerns resolving instances that are generated from IPC benchmarks, the cost of each and the duration.

sections.heading: Preface
sections.text: This textbook is aimed at students of Physics, Physical Chemistry and Theoretical Chemistry. Here, the reader will be provided with basic knowledge of atomic and quantum physics at the level taught, for example, in the first chapters of our book The Physics of Atoms and Quantum. Here, the physics student will find material that should be included in the basic training of every physicist. Furthermore, the concepts presented in this book are intended to enable students to gain an understanding of the breadth and diversity of the field of molecular physics and its future as a fascinating field of research. For chemistry students, the concepts presented in this book provide a theoretical framework for this entire field of study. By means of these concepts, at least in principle, it is possible to reduce the enormous stock of empirical chemical knowledge to a few basic principles: that of quantum mechanics. In addition, modern physical methods, the basics of which are introduced here, are becoming increasingly important in chemistry.

sections.heading: 1 Fixed-Period Problems: The Sublinear Case
sections.text: With this chapter, the preparatory work is over, and we begin the search for periodic solutions for Hamiltonian systems. All this will happen in the convex case; that is, we will examine the limit problem x = JH ′ (t, x) x (0) = x (T) with H (t, ·), a convex function of x that goes to + ∞ when it is reversed.

referenceMentions.context: A detailed introduction to (single-objective) AI planning can be found in [1].
It is clear, however, that most planning problems are in fact multi-objective, as the optimal solution in real-world problems often involve some trade-off between makespan and cost [2].
0 to account for both makespan and cost [3,4,5], or using the new hooks for several objectives offered by PDDL 3.
In the case of makespan and cost, both to be minimized, each linear combination can be defined by a single parameter α in [0, 1].
We hence propose here to use some evenly spaced values for α (see Section 4), but only after both objectives have been scaled into [0,1].

The results in this section are a refined version of [1]; the minimality result of Proposition 14 was the first of its kind.
Again the duality approach enabled Clarke and Ekeland in [2] to treat the same problem in the convex-subquadratic case, with growth conditions on H only.
Recently, Michalek and Tarantello (see [3] and [4]) have obtained lower bound on the number of subharmonics of period kT , based on symmetry considerations and on pinching estimates, as in Sect.

metadata.abstractText: Most real-world Planning problems are multi-objective, trying to minimize both the makespan of the solution plan, and some cost of the actions involved in the plan. But most, if not all existing approaches are based on single-objective planners, and use an aggregation of the objectives to remain in the single-objective context. Divide-andEvolve is an evolutionary planner that won the temporal deterministic satisficing track at the last International Planning Competitions (IPC). Like all Evolutionary Algorithms (EA), it can easily be turned into a Pareto-based Multi-Objective EA. It is however important to validate the resulting algorithm by comparing it with the aggregation approach: this is the goal of this paper. The comparative experiments on a recently proposed benchmark set that are reported here demonstrate the usefulness of going Pareto-based in AI Planning.
